Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Benjamin Knudsen is "Factorization homology and the topology of configuration spaces of manifolds." The host institution for the fellowship is Harvard University, and the sponsoring scientist is Michael Hopkins.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI held a Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (award DMS-1606422) while a postdoctoral fellow at Harvard University. Under this support, the PI (and collaborators) produced five journal articles and two preprints. The PI spoke extensively on this research at conferences and seminars and taught a related topics course at Harvard, which led to an expository book draft. 

The PI's research applies modern techniques to a classical problem of perennial interest in algebraic topology, namely the (co)homology of configuration spaces. Configuration spaces are fundamental objects in a host of subfields of pure mathematics, as well as in applied fields such as robotics. More specifically, the PI exploits in computation the rich algebraic structures emerging from two modern theoretical vantages on configuration spaces. The first is local-to-global, drawing on the theories of factorization homology and factorization algebras of Ayala, Francis, Lurie, Salvatore, Tanaka, and others, following Beilinson and Drinfeld. The second is asymptotic, growing out of the recent flush of interest in stability phenomena and representations of combinatorial categories following the seminal work of Church, Ellenberg, and Farb on representation stability.

The PI's work during the tenure of the award represents a fundamental contribution to the conceptual and computational understanding of the algebraic topology of configuration spaces of manifolds. In addition, it spearheaded the renaissance of the study of configuration spaces of graphs, which has since emerged as a subfield of notable interest.
